item.description:
For this event’s topic: skepticism, cynicism and Epicureanism we suggest turning to various encyclopedias in libraries and to the internet. We are working on posting complete texts and/or suggesting more concrete readings. For starter see some suggestions at the end of this message. Also here are some questions to think about:
What did these three schools have in common?
Where did they disagree?
How was it that one human life, that of Socrates, inspired so many disparate interpretations, philosophies and ways of life?

Resources:
The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy (http://www.iep.utm.ed....
Skepticism: http://www.iep.utm.ed...
Cynicism http://www.iep.utm.ed...
Epicureanism http://www.iep.utm.ed...

For original texts also check:
http://www.perseus.tu...
http://www.epicurus.n...
http://classics.mit.e...

For next Thursday’s meeting I would like to suggest some more readings:
Mike suggests that the followings are worthwhile to read about Epicurianism:
Principal Doctrines | Vatican Sayings | Letter to Menoeceus | Letter to Herodotus all are at: www.epicurus.net/index.html. Letter to Pythocles is interesting for those whore more inclined towards cosmology.

Does anyone have suggestions, knowledge what original works we have available from the ancient skeptics and cynics? I think we pretty much can cover Epicurianism, apart from Lucretius’ work On the Nature of Things. To my surprise (pleasant surprise) Epicurus has more to say about Nature compared to society than I thought before. If there is interest we can think about Lucretius for the following event?!

There is a nice article about Epicurus on the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (http://plato.stanford...) the article itself is at:
http://plato.stanford...
